title: Stuart Duff
text:
Stuart Duff (born 23 January 1982) is a Scottish retired professional <a href="association%20football">footballer</a> who last played for <a href="Inverurie%20Loco%20Works%20F.C.">Inverurie Loco Works</a> in the <a href="Highland%20Football%20League">Highland Football League</a>. He was primarily a central <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a> although his versatility saw him play in most defensive and midfield positions.
Duff began his career with <a href="Dundee%20United%20F.C.">Dundee United</a>, going on to make 171 first team appearances in nine years at the club. He later played for <a href="Aberdeen%20F.C.">Aberdeen</a> and <a href="Inverness%20Caledonian%20Thistle%20F.C.">Inverness Caledonian Thistle</a>, before leaving Scotland for spells with <a href="Qormi%20F.C.">Qormi</a> in Malta and <a href="FC%20Kairat">Kairat</a> in Kazakhstan. He joined <a href="Cove%20Rangers%20F.C.">Cove Rangers</a> in 2014, then signed for Inverurie Loco Works in 2017.
He is a former <a href="Scotland%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Scotland under-21</a> internationalist, having made ten appearances between 2002 and 2003.
Career.
Dundee United.
Having been developed as a player through <a href="Dundee%20United%20F.C.">Dundee United</a>'s youth scheme, he turned professional with the club in July 1999. He was given his debut by then-manager <a href="Alex%20Smith%20%28footballer%20born%201939%29">Alex Smith</a> in December 2001, when he was used as a right wing back in a match at <a href="Kilmarnock%20F.C.">Kilmarnock</a>, and went on to make nine appearances that season, collecting the April 'Young Player of the Month' award. In <a href="2002%E2%80%9303%20Scottish%20Premier%20League">2002–03</a>, Duff had his best run of league games, playing 34 times. When <a href="Ian%20McCall%20%28footballer%29">Ian McCall</a> was appointed at the start of the <a href="2003%E2%80%9304%20Scottish%20Premier%20League">2003–04 season</a>, Duff found himself more often as a substitute, playing in just 18 league games. During that season, Duff was part of the <a href="Scotland%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Scotland under-21</a> side that narrowly missed out on qualifying for the <a href="2004%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Football%20Championship">2004 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship</a>, with Scotland losing to Croatia in the play-off. The following season, Duff played 25 league games, earning him a new three-year contract in March 2005. Shortly afterwards, Duff was part of the United side that lost narrowly to <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a> in the <a href="Scottish%20Cup">Scottish Cup</a> final, with his 83rd-minute <a href="Substitute%20%28football%29">substitute</a> appearance earning him a runners-up medal.
In <a href="2005%E2%80%9306%20Scottish%20Premier%20League">2005–06</a>, with <a href="Gordon%20Chisholm">Gordon Chisholm</a> the new manager, Duff played more first team games, with 29 league appearances. During February 2006, Duff alleged he was <a href="Spitting">spat</a> on by <a href="Hearts%20F.C.">Hearts</a> midfielder <a href="Rudi%20Skacel">Rudi Skacel</a>, a claim repeated two months later by Celtic captain <a href="Neil%20Lennon">Neil Lennon</a>. No action was taken against Skacel in either incident. Duff scored an important goal in the 1–0 win over <a href="Rangers%20F.C.">Rangers</a> at <a href="Ibrox%20Stadium">Ibrox</a> during the season, which helped United avoid relegation. Duff started the <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20in%20Scottish%20football">2006–07 season</a> as an attacking midfielder under <a href="Craig%20Brewster">Craig Brewster</a> and scored once, although was used in a variety of defensive roles under <a href="Craig%20Levein">Craig Levein</a>.
Aberdeen.
In January 2008, Levein told Duff he was free to leave <a href="Tannadice%20Park">Tannadice</a> and find himself a new club. He was released on 17 January, after playing 170 games for the club, scoring four times. Duff began training with fellow <a href="Scottish%20Premier%20League">SPL</a> side <a href="Aberdeen%20F.C.">Aberdeen</a> and a short-term move to his home town club was confirmed the following day, seeing him become the third player to move from Tannadice to <a href="Pittodrie%20Stadium">Pittodrie</a> in eighteen months, following <a href="Lee%20Miller%20%28footballer%29">Lee Miller</a> and <a href="Lee%20Mair">Lee Mair</a>. Within six weeks of arriving, however, Duff was one of several players manager <a href="Jimmy%20Calderwood">Jimmy Calderwood</a> threatened to release at the end of the season, due to the club's poor performances. In May 2008, Duff instead signed a two-year contract extension with Aberdeen.
Inverness Caledonian Thistle.
Duff was loaned to <a href="Inverness%20Caledonian%20Thistle%20F.C.">Inverness CT</a> for a month in December 2009.
After his release by Aberdeen, Duff had a trial spell with <a href="St%20Johnstone%20F.C.">St Johnstone</a> and turned down an approach from <a href="St%20Mirren%20F.C.">St Mirren</a> before signing for <a href="Inverness%20Caledonian%20Thistle%20F.C.">Inverness CT</a>. Duff agreed a deal that was to run until the end of the 2010–11 season. Throughout the 2010/11 season he was a regular starter for Caley, and featured in most of their surprising results. These included a 1–1 draw against Rangers at Ibrox and a 2–2 draw with Celtic at Parkhead. His contract expired with ICT at the end of the 2010/11 season, and he stated his desire to stay with Inverness and said he would accept their contract offer after returning from holiday. In the summer of 2011, a contract was offered, but no deal was agreed and the contract offer was eventually withdrawn.
Playing Abroad.
Duff played three games for <a href="Ayr%20United%20F.C.">Ayr United</a> as a trialist in September 2011.
In November 2011, Duff agreed to join <a href="Qormi%20F.C.">Qormi</a>, in the <a href="Maltese%20Premier%20League">Maltese Premier League</a>, for the remainder of the season.
Kairat.
In February 2012, Duff agreed to join <a href="Kazakhstan%20Premier%20League">Kazakhstan Premier League</a> side <a href="FC%20Kairat">FC Kairat</a> on a lucrative one-year deal and was given the number 21 shirt. Duff scored his first goal for Kairat in their 2–0 victory over <a href="FC%20Sunkar">FC Sunkar</a> on 8 April 2012. Kairat finished the season in 10th place. Duff had his contract extended for another year, keeping him at the club till the end of the 2013 season. Duff left Kairat at the end of the 2013 season, as <a href="Kazakhstan%20Premier%20League">Kazakhstan Premier League</a> rules state that foreign players over the age of 30 must be playing for their national team in order to play in their league.
Highland League.
On 14 October 2014, Duff signed a short-term deal with <a href="Highland%20Football%20League">Highland Football League</a> side <a href="Cove%20Rangers%20F.C.">Cove Rangers</a>. In January 2015, Duff signed a new two-and-a-half year contract with the club, despite interest from <a href="Scottish%20League%20Two">Scottish League Two</a> side <a href="Montrose%20F.C.">Montrose</a>. In January 2017, he was transferred to another Highland League club, <a href="Inverurie%20Loco%20Works%20F.C.">Inverurie Loco Works</a>.
After Football.
After returning from a two-year spell in <a href="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a> with <a href="FC%20Kairat">FC Kairat</a>, Duff began working in the Oil & Gas sector in his native <a href="Aberdeen">Aberdeen</a> for <a href="Halliburton">Halliburton</a>. Duff also began scouting youngsters in Scotland for <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C">Manchester City</a> youth in early 2016.
In September 2021 he rejoined with Aberdeen again in the position of Youth Phase Manager.
